clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of Information Displays A Paper & Pencil, Computer, Simulator, and ICU Based Study
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of Information Displays A Paper & Pencil, Computer, Simulator, and ICU Based Study

collaborator.agency: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI)

brief_summary.textblock: Our objective is to develop intuitive, meaningful and ergonomically efficient informative displays specific to the user's domain. Specifically we aim to enhance and refine the display prototype of ABG information to include gas-exchange, acid-base balance, lung mechanics, ventilation, oxygenation, and metabolism information.

detailed_description.textblock: To create an intuitive and meaningful visualization of Arterial Blood Gas (ABG) variables, it is necessary to address usability, ergonomics, domain specific, and expertise specific issues and concerns. Our objective is to develop intuitive, meaningful and ergonomically efficient informative displays specific to the user's domain. Specifically we aim to enhance and refine the display prototype of ABG information to include gas-exchange, acid-base balance, lung mechanics, ventilation, oxygenation, and metabolism information.

primary_outcome.measure: Nurses using the new ICU display will detect and communicate to an attending physician (confederate) more abnormal patient physiological states than when using the tabular (control) display.

arm_group.description: ICU nurses who viewed the new ICU display visualization
ICU nurses who did not view the new ICU display visualization, but instead viewed a traditional "spreadsheet" style presentation of ICU trends of data

criteria.textblock: Inclusion Criteria: ICU nurses Exclusion Criteria: All participants were screened and excluded from participation if they had previously participated in any of graphical display design and feedback sessions when developing the ICU display.
